package_name: Egyptian Odyssey: The Land of Pharaohs and Ancient Wonders

places_to_visit.name: Pyramids of Giza
places_to_visit.description: The Pyramids of Giza are one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and a symbol of Egypt's rich history. Located on the outskirts of Cairo, the site includes the Great Pyramid of Khufu, the Pyramid of Khafre, and the Pyramid of Menkaure, along with the iconic Sphinx. These ancient structures have fascinated travelers for centuries and offer a glimpse into the architectural prowess of the ancient Egyptians.

places_to_visit.name: The Sphinx
places_to_visit.description: The Great Sphinx of Giza is a limestone statue of a reclining sphinx, a mythical creature with the body of a lion and the head of a human. The Sphinx stands on the Giza Plateau, near the Pyramids of Giza, and is believed to have been built during the reign of Pharaoh Khafre around 2500 BC. It is one of the largest and oldest statues in the world, shrouded in mystery and legends.

places_to_visit.name: Egyptian Museum
places_to_visit.description: Located in Cairo, the Egyptian Museum is home to an extensive collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts, including the treasures of Tutankhamun. The museum offers a fascinating journey through the history of Egypt, with exhibits showcasing mummies, jewelry, statues, and artifacts from different periods of ancient Egyptian civilization. It is a must-visit for anyone interested in Egyptology.

places_to_visit.name: Karnak Temple
places_to_visit.description: Karnak Temple, located in Luxor, is one of the largest religious complexes in the world. The temple was dedicated to the Theban triad of Amun, Mut, and Khonsu and was built over a span of 2,000 years. Visitors can explore the massive columns of the Hypostyle Hall, the sacred lake, and the various chapels and shrines. The temple complex is a testament to the grandeur of ancient Egyptian architecture and religious practices.

places_to_visit.name: Valley of the Kings
places_to_visit.description: The Valley of the Kings is a burial site for the pharaohs and powerful nobles of the New Kingdom (16th to 11th century BC). Located on the west bank of the Nile near Luxor, the valley contains over 60 tombs, including the famous tomb of Tutankhamun. Visitors can explore the intricately decorated tombs, which provide insight into the beliefs and burial practices of the ancient Egyptians.

places_to_visit.name: Temple of Hatshepsut
places_to_visit.description: The Temple of Hatshepsut, located in Deir el-Bahari near Luxor, is one of the most impressive mortuary temples in Egypt. It was built for the female pharaoh Hatshepsut, who ruled Egypt during the 18th Dynasty. The temple is known for its unique architectural design, which blends seamlessly into the surrounding cliffs. The terraces, colonnades, and statues make this temple a masterpiece of ancient Egyptian architecture.

places_to_visit.name: Abu Simbel Temples
places_to_visit.description: The Abu Simbel Temples, located in southern Egypt near the border with Sudan, are two massive rock-cut temples built by Pharaoh Ramses II in the 13th century BC. The larger temple is dedicated to Ramses II, while the smaller one is dedicated to his wife, Queen Nefertari. The temples are renowned for their colossal statues and intricate carvings. In the 1960s, the temples were relocated to higher ground to save them from flooding caused by the Aswan High Dam.

places_to_visit.name: Aswan High Dam
places_to_visit.description: The Aswan High Dam, located near the city of Aswan, is one of the most significant engineering projects of the 20th century. The dam was built across the Nile River to control flooding, provide water for irrigation, and generate hydroelectric power. Visitors can learn about the construction of the dam, its impact on Egypt, and enjoy panoramic views of Lake Nasser, one of the largest man-made lakes in the world.

places_to_visit.name: Philae Temple
places_to_visit.description: Philae Temple, located on Agilkia Island near Aswan, is dedicated to the goddess Isis and is one of the most beautiful temples in Egypt. The temple was relocated to its current location as part of the UNESCO Nubia Campaign to save it from the rising waters of the Nile caused by the construction of the Aswan High Dam. The temple complex is known for its beautiful reliefs and the scenic views of the Nile.

places_to_visit.name: Alexandria
places_to_visit.description: Alexandria, located on the Mediterranean coast, is Egypt's second-largest city and a cultural hub with a rich history. Founded by Alexander the Great, the city was a center of learning and culture in the ancient world. Visitors can explore historical sites such as the Catacombs of Kom El Shoqafa, the Roman Amphitheatre, and the Qaitbay Citadel, as well as the modern Bibliotheca Alexandrina, a stunning library and cultural center.

places_to_visit.name: Nile River Cruise
places_to_visit.description: A Nile River cruise is one of the most relaxing and scenic ways to explore Egypt. Cruises typically travel between Luxor and Aswan, passing by temples, villages, and lush landscapes. Onboard, visitors can enjoy luxury amenities, traditional entertainment, and guided tours to various historical sites along the way. The cruise offers a unique perspective of Egypt's timeless beauty and ancient history.

activities: Exploring ancient temples and tombs
Cruising on the Nile River
Learning about ancient Egyptian history and culture
Visiting iconic landmarks like the Pyramids and Sphinx
Experiencing traditional Egyptian cuisine
tips_and_tricks: Egypt can be hot, especially in the summer, so pack light, breathable clothing.
When visiting religious sites, dress modestly and respect local customs.
Bargaining is common in markets; don't hesitate to negotiate prices.
Stay hydrated, especially when exploring outdoor sites.

activities: Arrival at Cairo International Airport and transfer to the hotel
Afternoon visit to the Egyptian Museum for an introductory tour of ancient Egyptian artifacts
Evening free time to explore Cairo or relax at the hotel
Dinner at Abou El Sid, a traditional Egyptian restaurant
Morning visit to the Pyramids of Giza, including a guided tour of the Great Pyramid and the Sphinx
Explore the Solar Boat Museum, where an ancient Egyptian boat is on display
Lunch at a local restaurant with views of the pyramids
Afternoon visit to Saqqara to see the Step Pyramid of Djoser
Return to Cairo and dinner at Felfela, known for its Egyptian dishes
Morning flight from Cairo to Luxor
Transfer to the hotel and check-in
Afternoon visit to Karnak Temple, exploring the Hypostyle Hall and sacred lake
Evening visit to Luxor Temple, beautifully lit up at night
Dinner at the hotel’s 1886 Restaurant
Morning visit to the Valley of the Kings, including the tombs of Tutankhamun and Ramses VI
Explore the Temple of Hatshepsut, known for its unique design and historical significance
Lunch at a local restaurant in Luxor
Afternoon visit to the Colossi of Memnon and Medinet Habu
Return to the hotel and dinner at El Hussein Restaurant
Morning embarkation on a Nile River cruise from Luxor to Aswan
Cruise down the Nile, enjoying the scenic views and onboard amenities
Visit the Temple of Edfu, dedicated to the falcon god Horus
Lunch and dinner onboard the cruise
Continue the Nile River cruise with a stop at the Temple of Kom Ombo, dedicated to Sobek and Horus
Onboard activities, including traditional Egyptian music and dance
Relaxation on the sun deck or at the pool
Lunch and dinner onboard the cruise
Morning arrival in Aswan and disembarkation from the cruise
Visit the Philae Temple, known for its beautiful reliefs and island setting
Explore the Aswan High Dam and learn about its significance to Egypt
Lunch at a local restaurant in Aswan
Afternoon visit to the Unfinished Obelisk, showcasing ancient stone-working techniques
Evening free time to explore Aswan or relax at the hotel
Dinner at the hotel’s 1902 Restaurant
Early morning excursion to the Abu Simbel Temples, a UNESCO World Heritage site
Guided tour of the temples, including the Great Temple of Ramses II
Return to Aswan for lunch
Afternoon felucca ride on the Nile, exploring the botanical gardens and Elephantine Island
Dinner at Nubian House Restaurant, offering traditional Nubian cuisine
Morning flight from Aswan to Cairo and transfer to Alexandria
Visit the Catacombs of Kom El Shoqafa, an ancient necropolis
Explore the Roman Amphitheatre and the Qaitbay Citadel
Lunch at a seafood restaurant along the Corniche
Afternoon visit to the Bibliotheca Alexandrina, a modern library and cultural center
Return to Cairo and dinner at Sequoia, a restaurant on the Nile
Free day to explore Cairo at your leisure or take an optional day trip to the nearby city of Memphis
Visit the Hanging Church and the Coptic Museum in Old Cairo
Lunch at a local restaurant in Old Cairo
Afternoon visit to Khan El Khalili Bazaar for shopping and souvenirs
Return to the hotel for a farewell dinner
Morning visit to the Alabaster Mosque (Mosque of Muhammad Ali) in the Citadel of Saladin
Explore Islamic Cairo, including the Sultan Hassan Mosque and Al-Rifa'i Mosque
Lunch at a local restaurant in Islamic Cairo
Afternoon visit to the Museum of Islamic Art or a walk through Al-Muizz Street
Evening free time to relax or enjoy a Nile dinner cruise
Check-out from the hotel and transfer to Cairo International Airport for departure
